awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrating field geomorphology, remote sensing, undergraduate education, and  modelling to improve understanding of Arctic hydrology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is undergoing rapid changes as this sensitive region responds to altered energy and water transport at the global scale, deeply affecting its local communities, ecosystems, and water cycle. One of the best ways to catalog and understand these changes is through the study of Arctic rivers. Rivers are an excellent indicator of overall Arctic change as the water in the river at any given time (its "discharge") is a reflection of all of the other components of the water and energy cycles: precipitation, evaporation, and groundwater movements. However, logistical difficulties and shifting international priorities have resulted in a steep decline in gauge monitoring  network. Likewise, the unique geomorphology (the way rivers shape and are shaped by the landscape) of Arctic rivers is relatively understudied. Without advances in open source data and understanding of Arctic rivers we lack the ability to assess recent Artic changes that are affecting citizens and ecosystems alike, and our ability to accurately predict the future climate and water resources of the Arctic is greatly impaired.

Therefore, this project seeks an unprecedented accounting of the pan-Arctic hydrologic cycle built from the river up. The project will first develop the basic open-source river data needed to assess recent changes in Arctic hydrology and then use these data to catalog and understand the state of the Arctic's water. Specifically, the project will couple the recent explosion in big-data remote sensing and specific remote sensing discharge estimation techniques with classic fluvial geomorphology to estimate discharge for every Arctic river wider than 150m from 1984 to present using NASA's Landsat family of satellites. This remotely sensed Arctic river assessment will be founded upon a backbone of detailed fieldwork as designed and executed by undergraduates at UMass Amherst in a new program: Integrating Geosciences and Engineering in the Arctic (IGEA). IGEA participants will design and lead fieldwork intended to deepen understanding of unique Arctic geomorphology, and this information will be absorbed to improve the discharge estimates made from remote sensing. IGEA students will design field experiments in the spring semester as juniors, perform Arctic fieldwork in the summer after their junior year, and then analyze their data and train the next cohort of participants in the fall of their senior year. Undergraduates are purposefully drawn from two different disciplines, Engineering and Geosciences, to address disciplinary siloing at the undergraduate level and to train, teach, and inspire the next generation of interdisciplinary thinkers through this immersive Arctic research program. Finally, the IGEA-informed remotely sensed discharge data will be used to calibrate an open source global hydrology model, integrating the other components of this project to reach a fuller understanding of the entire Arctic system achieved through improved process-based understanding of Arctic rivers.

por.por_cntn:
This award led to the most detailed and accurate map of streamflows across the Arctic ever produced. We found larger and more heterogenous total water export (3-17% greater) and water export acceleration (factor of 1.2-3.3 larger) from Artic rivers to the Arctic Ocean than previously reported, with substantial differences across basins, ecoregions, stream orders, human regulation, and permafrost regimes. We can map, for the first time, not only which regions are drying or wetting under climate change but also which individual river reaches are doing so. We also find significant changes in the spring freshet and summer stream intermittency. We did so by calculating daily streamflow in 486,493 pan-Arctic river reaches from 1984-2018 by assimilating 9.18 million river discharge estimates made from 155,710 satellite images into hydrologic model simulations. This major result could affect any hydrological, biological, or geochemical analysis that uses river discharge as its basis. We published the paper as open access in Nature Communications and have permanently and freely archived the data.

We also performed the world’s first comprehensive survey of beaded streams: a unique Arctic river form about which little is known. We found more than 80,000 beaded streams globally, surpassing previous estimates that there were likely less than 10,000 of these streams. Thus, we have shown that beaded streams are far more ubiquitous a morphology than previously thought and that they exist in a much broader range of geologic and geomorphic settings.

These above breakthroughs rest on a host of new knowledge required to generate them involving river theory, computational techniques, and remote sensing methods. These five other publications go in-depth to form the body of evidence for us to make the leaps in understanding described above.

At the time of writing, we have two other major outcomes that are complete but have not yet been peer reviewed. We have repeated our individual river streamflow mapping for all rivers on the planet and revealed unexpected profiles of stream power (sediment moving ability) and that rivers are shifting their flows upstream. We have also applied superresolution fusion of satellites to rivers to map individual river suspended sediment. If we combine the discharge and sediment mapping, we can now map the sediment load moving through any river on earth. These results must be verified by peer review, but are major outcomes of this award.

Finally, this award funded the direct participation of three cohorts of undergraduates in Arctic fieldwork.  The students spent a semester formulating a field plan and arranging and receiving safety and logistics training, and then travelled to Alaska to complete fieldwork, and then spent the following semester analyzing the data. They made contributions to the body of scientific knowledge of beaded streams: they measured more streams in situ than any previous study, and they discovered interesting similarities between beaded and non beaded streams of similar size. For instance, they report that width/depth ratios are statistically the same, but that active layer thickness is statistically different between beaded and alluvial channels of similar widths. The students also organized a poster session and panel discussion that was attended by over 50 people, including the Dean of the College of Engineering at UMass. The students stand transformed by their exposure to scientists at in Alaska and to professionals at UMass, coupled with their training in scientific method and specific certifications like wilderness first responder for two of the class members. This grant enabled all students to participate at no cost to them, which enabled students to participate when they otherwise would never have the opportunity to do so. Of the 20 total students to move through the program, seven changed their career goals and have since gone to graduate school to continue research: a measurable impact of this class/grant.
